race.name: FNLD GRVL
race.tagline: The happiest gravel in the world. F1 glamour meets midnight sun in a UNESCO Geopark. Fast, flat, and fckng Finnish.

vitals.aid_stations: Fully stocked aid stations throughout course

climate.primary: Mild Nordic summer with extended daylight
climate.description: August in Lahti means pleasant 21C highs (70F), with lows around 10C (50F). The white nights phenomenon provides near-24-hour daylight, with sunset after 11 PM and sunrise at 4 AM. Variable weather possible with occasional rain showers. Pack for layers and potential rain.
challenges: Temperature swings of 15C within a week
Mosquitoes and elk flies in forest areas

terrain.primary: Fast-rolling Finnish gravel roads through UNESCO Geopark
terrain.surface: Mix of gravel, tarmac, and Nordic ski paths. Well-maintained public gravel roads, some loose stony gravel on hills
features: Ancient bedrock outcrops (2 billion years old)

logistics.explanation: Helsinki-Vantaa Airport offers good international connections, with Lahti just 1 hour by train or bus. Miranda rode 165km from Helsinki to Lahti on "perfect smooth, gravel roads and paths," demonstrating excellent infrastructure. However, Finland remains expensive and accommodation options in small-city Lahti are limited for race weekend.

length.explanation: The 177km Midnight Sun Route earned elite-level respect. Graham Cottingham finished in 6hrs 3mins averaging 35kph on Nordic ski paths, while pros like Toms Skujins completed it in 4hrs 46mins. Miranda found racing the distance "completely different" from her usual endurance training days, requiring tactical group management throughout. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Graham Cottingham described "champagne gravel roads" that are "technically easy to ride" compared to "rugged Scottish gravel tracks." The course uses well-maintained Finnish infrastructure roads with some undulating cross-country ski trails. Javi Angulo noted "wide gravel paths" that allow tactical racing rather than technical bike handling challenges. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Elite observers noted "most of the elevation gain comes from rolling gravel paths and not a climb in particular," with only "a steep ramp 13km from the finish" standing out. Elle described the climbing as "relentless" but Graham Cottingham found the "almost constant false flat effect" more challenging than any single ascent. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 66°F and lows of 55°F, with a 60% chance of rain on any given day. Race day 2023 brought sunshine with slight wind after Thursday's rain, warm enough for sunburn despite being cooler than UK temperatures. Elle packed "3 pairs of gloves for every season" based on organizer warnings about unpredictable weather. Javi Angulo joked "We got a tan in Finland, who would have thought?" during his August test ride. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Lahti sits essentially at sea level with maximum course elevation of 216m. The finish climb that Elle described as "looking vertical" is actually a ski slope, not a mountain ascent. Zero altitude concerns for any rider coming from normal elevations. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Racing through a UNESCO Global Geopark under 19 hours of June daylight creates unique adventure. Miranda described "quaint wooden houses painted red or yellow" with locals "waving and cheering," while the "sheer vastness of the landscape skewed distance and time." Javi Angulo called it "one of the best gravel courses we had ever ridden."

prestige.explanation: Founded by F1 driver Valtteri Bottas and WorldTour pro Tiffany Cromwell in partnership with the SBT GRVL team. Part of the UCI Gravel World Series ecosystem. Finland will host the 2027 UEC European Gravel Championships in Lahti. International media coverage and WorldTour pro participation (10% of field). Not Unbound-level iconic, but prestigious.

race_quality.explanation: SBT GRVL team brings top-tier event production expertise. F1-level professionalism meets gravel racing. Fully stocked aid stations, marked routes, post-race meal, evening award ceremony, 4-day festival proceedings with shakedown rides and yoga. Strong sustainability focus. This is premium event organization.

experience.explanation: Suvi Loponen described riding "sheltered by pine and birch trees which filtered the sun," with "crushing of smooth gravel" that wasn't "too obtrusive to prevent chatting." Miranda enjoyed the mix of challenging racing and "new friendships as we hammered along to the finish," embodying the event's "spirit of gravel" tagline.

community.explanation: Strong inclusive culture with family-friendly 4-day festival. Post-race beer culture with all participants. Mix of 150+ WorldTour professionals and first-time gravel racers. Focus on environmental sustainability and climate change advocacy. The Nordic gravel community is growing rapidly with the event as a centerpiece.

field_depth.explanation: 10% pro field including WorldTour names like Toms Skujins (inaugural winner), Greg Van Avermaet, Petr Vakoc, and Andre Greipel. Tiffany Cromwell has won both editions. EUR 20,000 inaugural prize purse (reduced to EUR 7,000 in 2025). Racing at the front with UCI Gravel World Series connection. Deeper field than most — comparable to Badlands. As Graham Cottingham puts it: "It was clear from the start this was definitely a race, as very quickly the riding was flat out as racers jostled for positions on the first climb."

value.explanation: Strong inclusions like marked GPS routes, aid stations, post-race meals, and finisher gear justify the premium positioning. The 4-day festival format with activities provides depth beyond just race day. However, specific pricing remains opaque beyond the $1,000 VIP package, making value assessment difficult for budget-conscious riders.

expenses.explanation: Finland ranks among Europe's most expensive countries with the VIP package alone costing $1,000 USD. Elle's extensive gear list reflects the need for multiple clothing options due to weather unpredictability. International flights, Nordic accommodation costs, and high food prices easily push total trip expenses above $2,000 for overseas participants. Higher total cost than Badlands.

biased_opinion.summary: FNLD GRVL is what happens when an F1 driver falls in love with gravel. It's not the most challenging course or the deepest pro field, but for a unique Nordic cultural experience wrapped in world-class event production, it delivers. The midnight sun, the UNESCO Geopark, the Finnish hospitality, and the SBT GRVL pedigree create something genuinely special.
strengths: World-class event production from SBT GRVL team
Unique midnight sun and Nordic cultural experience
UNESCO Geopark setting with stunning lakes and forests
Strong pro field with WorldTour participation
weaknesses: Expensive destination with high total trip costs
Relatively flat with limited climbing challenge
Mosquitoes and bugs in summer forest terrain
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A bucket-list Nordic gravel experience for those who value culture, scenery, and event quality over extreme physical challenge. Worth the trip for the unique experience; not worth it if you're only chasing climbing meters.

black_pill.title: THE BUGS, THE COST, AND THE DECLINING NUMBERS
black_pill.reality: Finland's summer brings the 'rakka' season of mosquitoes and elk flies. Close-fitting cycling clothes allow mosquitoes to bite through. Elk flies are considered worse than mosquitoes by locals. Ticks carrying Lyme disease are present. And then there's the money: Finland is expensive, VIP packages are $1,000, and your total trip will easily hit $2,000+. Meanwhile, participation has dropped from 1,000 riders (2023) to 700 riders (2024), with 2025 reimagined as the more casual 'FNLD TRVL'.
consequences: Bug spray is mandatory; expect bites during rest stops
Budget significantly more than for US or Southern European events
Event may be finding its sustainable format after initial hype
black_pill.expectation_reset: Bring serious bug repellent. Budget $2,500+ for the full international trip. Accept that this is a premium experience at premium prices. The event is finding its identity post-hype, which could mean either refinement or decline.

final_verdict.one_liner: F1 glamour meets Nordic gravel in a UNESCO Geopark—premium experience, premium price tag, unique bucket-list appeal.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want a unique Nordic cultural experience with world-class event production. Yes if you're an F1/Bottas fan. Skip if you're chasing big climbing or watching your budget. International travelers should weigh the high costs against the unique experience.
final_verdict.alternatives: Dirty Reiver (UK, cheaper, more climbing); The Traka (Spain, bigger field, better weather); SBT GRVL (Colorado, same organizers, more established)

logistics.lodging_strategy: Book early in Lahti city center. Options include Scandic Lahti City, Solo Sokos Hotel, and Cumulus Lahti (cycling-friendly). Limited capacity for race weekend. Lake Paijanne accommodations offer scenic alternatives ~24km from station.
logistics.food: Aid stations fully stocked. Post-race meal included. Finland is expensive for dining out.
logistics.packet_pickup: Event weekend at Lahti. 4-day festival includes shakedown rides and activities.

history.founder: Valtteri Bottas, Tiffany Cromwell, Amy Charity (GRVL Events)
history.origin_story: Born from a chance encounter between F1 driver Valtteri Bottas and the American gravel racing scene. In 2021, Bottas participated in SBT GRVL in Steamboat Springs and was so impressed he approached the organizers about bringing a similar event to his hometown of Lahti, Finland. The partnership with Amy Charity's GRVL Events team created a premium Nordic gravel experience.
notable_moments: 2023: Inaugural edition draws 1,000+ riders from 27 countries
2023: Toms Skujins (Trek-Segafredo) wins men's race; Tiffany Cromwell wins women's by 9 minutes
2024: Markus Pajur wins men's in sprint finish; Cromwell defends title
2027: UEC European Gravel Championships confirmed for Lahti
history.reputation: The Nordic entry point to premium international gravel racing. F1 glamour meets Finnish hospitality.

course_description.character: Fast, flowing Finnish gravel through UNESCO Geopark terrain. Well-maintained gravel roads, lakeside routes, and Nordic ski paths create a high-speed experience rather than a technical challenge. The continuous undulations and steep kickers separate riders, but this is racing, not survival. Riders average 35 kph on the twisting ski path sections.

suffering_zones.label: Forest Entrance
suffering_zones.desc: Where groups fragment on the first real climbs. The continuous undulations become apparent.

suffering_zones.label: Lake Circuit
suffering_zones.desc: Exposed lakeside sections where wind can play a factor. Beautiful but potentially draining.

suffering_zones.label: Ski Trail Sections
suffering_zones.desc: Twisting Nordic ski paths with steep kickers. Where legs that are already tired face relentless small climbs.

suffering_zones.label: Final Forest Push
suffering_zones.desc: For those on the Midnight Sun 177km route, mental and physical fatigue combine in remote forest sections.

course_description.signature_challenge: Not one killer climb, but the relentless accumulation of steep kickers and undulations that 'will separate' riders. Plus the bugs at every stop.

distance_options.name: Forest Route
distance_options.description: Beginner-friendly option through picturesque pine forests. Includes e-bike category. Ideal for first-time gravel riders.

distance_options.name: Lakes Route
distance_options.description: Moderate challenge routing around stunning Finnish lakes. 650m of climbing with max elevation 216m. Beautiful scenery throughout.

distance_options.name: Midnight Sun Route
distance_options.description: Most challenging option for experienced cyclists. Pro prize purse competition. Diverse terrain from forests to lakes under the enchanting light of the midnight sun.

videos.title: FNLD GRVL: Where is Lahti, Finland?
videos.description:
Where in the world is Lahti, Finland? If you've ridden there, then you you know. If not, then it's time to go. Join us right here on June 10th for Europe's newest gravel cycling race. From the team behind SBT GRVL and F1 legend Valtteri Bottas and women's champ ; welcome to FNLD GRVL. 

https://www.fnldgrvl.com

videos.title: Welcome to FNLD GRVL
videos.description:
Join us June 10th 2023 in Lahti Finland. A brainchild of Formula 1 driver Valtteri Bottas and SBT GRVL, the event will feature three course distances with a 20k Euro prize purse and 1500 riders from around the world.  

Registration opens November 15th and is expected to sell out quickly.

videos.title: Lahti Harbor: Starting Line for FNLD GRVL
videos.description: It’s hard to believe it right now in the dead of winter, but this icy harbor in downtown Lahti will soon thaw and come alive this June. Hundreds of riders from around the world will line up right here for the start of FNLD GRVL. Racers won’t have to worry about burning daylight as the sun will not set here until 10:49 pm on June tenth. This is great news for the night owls, because we’ll be partying late into the evening with music, awards, and of course, plenty of food and beer.

videos.title: FNLD GRVL Race Weekend Recap
videos.description:
The first edition of FNLD GRVL is officially in the books, and what a weekend it was. From shakeout rides with Valtteri Bottas and Tiffany Cromwell, to rides with Castelli, Canyon, Strava and Zipp, to a non-traditional pro panel featuring some of the biggest names in cycling we packed a ton into three days; and, that was all before we even rolled up to the starting line. On Saturday, June 10th nearly 1,000 gravel cyclists from around the world lined up in downtown Lahti, Finland, and we sent them off into the countryside and along three distances (177k, 77k, and 40k) through the pristine gravel roads of Finnish Lakeland. That night we brought it all to a close in typical GRVL fashion under the midnight sun in the Lahti harbor with awards, concert, DJ, and and afterparty complete with sauna and hot tubs. Catch our full day-by-day recap right here, and keep your eye out for 2024 registration dates and info.

rider_intel.search_text: The Finnish Gravel race starts in downtown Lahti harbor and finishes at the Lahti Sports Complex, known for its world famous ski jumps that serve as a beacon for riders approaching the finish line. The race takes place in June when Finland experiences extended daylight, with sunset not occurring until 10:49 PM on race day, giving riders plenty of natural light for the 110-mile course. The finish area hosts a weekend expo at the Sports Complex. Post-race festivities extend late into the evening and include music, awards ceremony, food and beer. The race attracts hundreds of international riders who gather in the harbor area for the start.
